Headline.Para: HOCK LOCK SIEW; SIAS-initiated sessions mostly constructive, but not all are useful

LeadPara.Para: THE heart-to-heart townhall meetings hosted by the Securities Investors' Association of Singapore (SIAS) to help companies' boards or management address disgruntled investors are no doubt useful.

They provide an additional avenue for unhappy investors to air their concerns (or in some cases, niggling suspicions) and also access to top officials of a company - an opportunity they otherwise may not have beyond the annual shareholder meetings.

TailParas.Para: During its fiscal 2017, the shareholder activist group organised 12 dialogue sessions - all well intentioned - to help shareholders make sense of corporate actions like a privatisation offer or restructuring plan, or to iron out worries over a company's accounts or financial health.

Some of the firms included SMRT, ARA Asset Management and Auric Pacific (privatisation offers) as well as Sabana Shari'ah Compliant Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust (Sabana Reit), which was facing a shareholder revolt and Si2i whose shareholders were worried about a lack of a viable plan to yank itself out of the Singapore Exchange's watch list.
These sessions are almost always timely.

About a year ago last April, a dialogue session was held as Sabana Reit's manager was facing a potential ouster from a group of unhappy unitholders, chiefly due to the Reit's languishing returns. The session was held about a week before an extraordinary general meeting requisitioned by some unitholders to, among other things, give the manager the boot.

That same evening, the Reit issued a statement on its presentation at the SIAS session that the resolutions, if passed, would harm investors' interests. This was, however, merely a drumming home of similar points already expressed earlier by the manager.
For some of these sessions, the issue of timely and fair disclosure is also worth looking into. Is the information disclosed at these company-shareholder dialogue sessions available to the public?

Does it give rise to selective disclosure, some of which involve price-sensitive information? This perhaps can be addressed by concurrent disclosures, or the dialogues can instead be held during a trading halt or over the weekend.

When shareholders of Cordlife Group were rattled over the sudden exit of its longtime chief Jeremy Yee two years ago, a SIAS-hosted session with shareholders unveiled fresh details on the factors that led to his departure.
None of these was captured in the presentation slides that Cordlife had lobbed on the Singapore Exchange website that same evening.

More recently, on March 7, a similar session was organised for YuuZoo Corp and its shareholders. One day after the event, YuuZoo said it informed investors who were present about a new organisational structure and provided more details on a joint-venture real estate project in China and logistics business in France.

Between March 7 and 9, YuuZoo's stock rose nearly 11 per cent, from 3.8 Singapore cents to 4.2 cents, reversing an earlier sell off. Indeed, governance expert Professor Mak Yuen Teen of NUS Business School surmised that the information disclosed at the dialogue and press release could have led to the swing in YuuZoo's share price.

While many of SIAS-initiated dialogues have been fruitful, some may be just overkill, like the one scheduled for March 26 and organised by SIAS for Datapulse Technology and investors amid a shareholder tussle. For one, it's tough to build bridges when investors are wary over the newly-installed board and management, which is the investors' main beef.

Also, the event will be held ahead of an EGM slated for April 20 that was requisitioned by the family of one of Datapulse's co-founders to oust the newly appointed directors and block a diversification plan. This shareholder fight arose after a new majority owner emerged at the firm last November.

There's a good chance that this session could serve as an additional platform for the company to expound its side of the story that has already been amply narrated through a string of announcements to date. Yet, it does also provide a chance for investors, especially those who are confounded by the back-to-back events at the company, to meet face-to-face with the embattled board before making a final decision at the EGM.

Unfortunately, this dialogue involving Datapulse, like most others, are closed-door events meant for shareholders and investors only. No media is allowed. This is ironic given that better transparency is the chief purpose of such events.
In short, while the SIAS-led dialogues are meant to be constructive - and they are in most cases - the activist body may still need to fine-tune some aspects of its well-meaning agenda.
